I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  While space-based technology (SBT) has made tremendous advances, this technology 
has yet to be exploited in supporting evidence-based policy making in Asia and the Pacific. 
Several pilot countries in receipt of regional policy and advisory technical assistance (TA)1 have 
expressed keen interest in adopting SBT for estimating crop areas and forecasting production, 
because this technology is known to provide more reliable and timely measurements. In addition, 
it can be used in early warning systems for drought and in measuring flooding. However, while 
literature on SBT is fairly abundant, developing countries find accessing and consequently using 
SBT very challenging, if not unfeasible, without external technical advice.  
 
2.  The use of SBT in Asian Development Bank (ADB) projects is also still in its infancy. 
Recent developments in this area are (i) the agreement between ADB and the Japan Aerospace 
Exploration Agency (JAXA) to promote disaster management, climate change mitigation and 
adaptation, forest monitoring, and water resources management in Asia and the Pacific by using 
SBT (mainly remote sensing); and (ii) implementation of regional TA under which JAXA agreed 
to assist ADB in applying SBT and information and communication technology for flood risk 
management and training staff of concerned agencies in three pilot countries—Bangladesh, 
Philippines, and Viet Nam.2  
 
3.  This TA was conceptualized to promote the use of SBT in formulating and monitoring 
food security policies. Extensive discussions were held with prospective pilot countries and 
other research organizations that are also studying the use of SBT in agricultural statistics in 
Asia  and  the  Pacific—JAXA;  the  International  Rice  Research  Institute;  the  Philippine  Rice 
Research  Institute;  and  the  Geo-Informatics  and  Space  Technology  Development  Agency 
(GISTDA), Thailand. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. The TA received 
concept clearance from ADB Management in December 2012.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Timely and reliable crop production and area estimates are important in monitoring 
government development plans and in mitigating the effects of extreme weather and climate 
change. These statistics are usually compiled through either administrative reporting systems or 
household surveys. A closer look at the data compilation of many countries revealed that crop 
production and other agricultural statistics are collected from administrative reporting systems 
that are biased and unreliable. Government agricultural personnel assess crop production by 
observing harvests and by interviewing experts (village heads, farmers, and traders) in their 
assigned localities and reporting the estimates to their next level of bureaucracy, until the 
summary  statistics  reach  the  national  government.  While  this  data  collection  approach  is 
inexpensive, research has shown that it is prone to large measurement errors. Data collection 
officers and others involved in the process have vested interests that influence the estimation 
process. Agricultural officers tend to overestimate production in their assigned areas to support 
their claims of accomplishment. This type of administrative reporting does not usually include a 
validation process that could improve the quality of estimates. Inaccurate estimation of staple 
food production can lead to inappropriate policies and, consequently, unfavorable outcomes, 
and possibly worsening food security.

5.  If objectively designed and conducted, household surveys can provide better estimates 
and  sampling  error  estimates.  However,  measurement  errors  may  still  arise  because 
methodological  studies  suggest  that,  during  interviews,  farmers  may  inadvertently  provide 
inaccurate crop areas and production estimates. Instead of actual crop areas, farmers usually 
give the area of their total landholding, and this could include areas devoted to livestock and 
other activities. Intercropped areas are also difficult to measure. Production estimates would 
probably exclude areas provided to sharecroppers and land that was used for barter of services. 
Moreover, household surveys require large budget allocations and, hence, instead of being able 
to capture production data every quarter, countries usually conduct annual production surveys 
in which memory recall is often a significant issue. Also, because household surveys take longer 
to process and analyze, their results do not reach the policy makers in time for planning the next 
cropping season. 
 
6.  More advanced countries in Asia and the Pacific have used satellite-based remote 
sensing and other information technology in estimating crop areas and production. Remote 
sensing and similar methods have also been used to quickly assess crop damage due to 
flooding and as an early warning system for drought. Processed satellite data could also be 
studied further for determining existing paddy field conditions, rice crop growth condition, and 
other  agro-meteorological  information  that  affects  rice  crop  production.  Unlike  household 
surveys that only measure one specific time period, satellite-based data are recorded more 
frequently and, hence, the rice cropping calendar can be analyzed further. With more timely and 
reliable data from remote sensing and other similar tools, estimates of rice crop area and 
production, even during times of calamity (e.g., damage caused by flood or drought), will be 
available for policy makers and government agencies to mitigate food security issues and 
design intervention for at-risk areas.   
 
7.  There have also been attempts to use remote sensing for agriculture and food security in 
developing countries in Asia and the Pacific. In Thailand, GISTDA, in close collaboration with 
JAXA, used remote sensing technology (such as synthetic aperture radar [SAR]) for estimating 
rice crop area and forecasting rice production in Khon Kaen province in 2011. The same 
technology was being applied in Suphanburi and Roet provinces in 2012. Under an Association 
of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  food  security  information  system  project,  agricultural  land 
information system crop areas in Vientiane in the Lao People's Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) 
were estimated using optical satellite imagery in Google Earth. The International Rice Research 
Institute is working with the Philippine Rice Research Institute in using satellite imagery to 
estimate rice areas to provide a better basis for micro-insurance purposes. In all of these cases, 
the success of these projects hinges on the effective upgrading of skills of counterpart staff in 
the concerned government agencies of developing countries. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The intended impact of the proposed TA is more evidence-based policies and programs 
on food security. The expected outcome is improved quality and timeliness of rice crop area and 
production estimates and forecasts. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will consist of three major activities: (i) development of customized software 
applications and methodology to estimate paddy rice cultivation area and crop production based

3 
on satellite data and in-situ data obtained through crop-cutting experiments at a provincial level 
for four  pilot  countries,  (ii) training  of counterpart  staff in the four  pilot  countries,  and  (iii) 
development of an online training program on the use of satellite data for agricultural and rural 
statistics.  
 
10.  The four pilot countries—the Lao PDR, the Philippines, Thailand, and Viet Nam—were 
chosen because of the substantial contribution of the agriculture sector to their economies and 
the large number of people still employed in agriculture. Thailand, the Philippines, and Viet Nam 
are major world rice producers, and the Philippines is also one of the world’s leading rice 
importers. The governments  of  these  pilot  countries  are  committed to  institutionalizing  the 
methods that will be developed under this project so that rice area and production estimates and 
early warning estimates of rice crop damage will be provided on a timely and regular basis to 
support better policy making for, and monitoring of, the agriculture sector.  
 
11.  To achieve timely results that can be fully validated, the TA will focus on one province in 
each pilot country, except for Thailand where previous projects have been conducted. The 
methods that will be developed will only be applied on paddy rice crop during the rainy season 
as a main crop using SAR and other satellite-based data with ground observation data. For 
Thailand, several provinces will be selected as pilot projects and both a crop model and ground 
observation data combined with satellite-based SAR and other data will be applied to estimate 
rice crop area and production. The pilot provinces will be selected in consultation with the 
respective implementing agencies using the following criteria: substantial contiguous paddy rice 
area, and the extent of contribution to the country’s rice production. 
 
12.  For each pilot country, the designated implementing agency will be responsible for 
adapting and applying the methods that will be explored. The methods that will be studied 
involve SAR and optical satellite data that are freely accessible. The choice of which method to 
adopt will be based on the robustness of the data given all types of weather conditions. For 
example, it is known that the application of optical data is fairly limited under cloudy conditions 
in which good temporal and spatial resolutions may not be fully achieved. Application programs 
that can interpret satellite data to distinguish rice crops and construct rice area maps, assess 
rice crop growth conditions, and provide early warning indicators of rice crop damage will be 
developed  and  customized  according to  the four  pilot  countries’ meteorological  conditions. 
Selected archived data will be used to test the application programs that will be developed in the 
first year. These archived data will also be used in the hands-on training programs that will be 
conducted for selected staff of implementing agencies. 
 
13.  Intensive  training  programs  will  be  conducted  for  counterpart  staff  of  implementing 
agencies, who will also work closely with the project team in (i) customizing the software 
applications so that these are integrated into existing systems of implementing agencies and, if 
needed,  include  interfaces  that  use  the  national  language;  and  (ii)  putting  the  software 
applications into production. Field surveys in the pilot provinces using rice crop cutting will be 
conducted  to  validate  the  results  of  the  methods  being  studied.  Training  for  field  survey 
personnel will be conducted prior to the field operations. Workshops on the results of the field 
surveys will be held to further improve both the systems applications and the field survey 
validation methods. 
 
14.   An online training program will be developed to promote the use of remote sensing for 
estimating crop area and forecasting production and to share the experiences of the four pilot 
countries in adopting this technology. The online training program will help to cost-effectively 
expand the user base of these methods.

4   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,639,000, of which $2,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. JAXA will provide 
counterpart support in the form of personnel cost, technical fees, and administration services. 
The value of JAXA’s contribution is estimated to account for 14.2% of the total TA cost. The 
governments of Lao PDR, the Philippines, Thailand and Viet Nam  will provide salaries of 
counterpart staff, office space, and administrative support. The value of government contribution 
is estimated to account for 10% of the total TA cost. The cost estimates and financing plan are 
in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB will be the executing agency of this TA. The Development Indicators and Policy 
Research Division will administer the technical assistance and will closely collaborate with all 
ADB units that are working on related issues, including the Sustainable Infrastructure Division; 
Environment, Natural Resources and Agriculture Division; Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) 
Core Agriculture Support Program;  and the Agriculture, Rural Development, and Food Security 
Community of Practice. The implementing agencies in the pilot countries are the Center for 
Statistics  and  Information,  Ministry  of  Agriculture  and  Forestry,  Lao  PDR;  the  Bureau  of 
Agricultural  Statistics,  Department  of  Agriculture,  the  Philippines;  the  Office  of  Agricultural 
Economics, Ministry of Agriculture and Cooperatives, and GISTDA, Thailand; and the Center for 
Informatics and Statistics, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Viet Nam. JAXA will 
be ADB’s technical adviser and development partner organization. GISTDA, having first applied 
the method, will also provide technical support. The TA will be implemented for 26 months from 
June 2013 to July 2015.   
 
17.  JAXA is also working with the Sustainable Infrastructure Division of the Regional and 
Sustainable Development Department on another project (footnote 2), and a similar agreement 
will be drawn for this project between JAXA and ADB. JAXA will be the project technical adviser 
and has agreed to provide expertise in the following areas: (i) applying remote sensing using 
existing rice crop application software in the Lao PDR, the Philippines, Thailand, and Viet Nam; 
(ii)  implementing  capacity  development  for  applying  remote  sensing;  and  (iii)  technical 
assistance in developing the online curriculum using remote sensing technology on agriculture 
and rural statistics. In addition, GISTDA in Thailand will provide technical advice for rice crop 
area and production estimation using SAR under the ongoing JAXA–GISTDA collaboration. 
 
18.  The implementing agencies will be responsible for processing the satellite data using the 
software applications that will be developed under the project so that pilot provincial crop area 
and production estimates can be generated. They will also undertake the field validation through 
the crop-cutting method. They will assign counterpart staff who will be trained in (i) the use and 
maintenance of the software applications so that this estimation method can be fully adopted, 
and (ii) implementing the field validation. The implementing agencies will closely coordinate with 
other bodies that comprise the national statistical system in the pilot countries to inform them of 
relevant project results and online training programs and promote the use of remote sensing 
technology for compilation of official statistics. They will also be responsible for disseminating 
the crop area and production estimates among policy makers and other concerned agencies.

5 
The online training program will be hosted on the Community for Agriculture and Rural Statistics 
website.4  
 
19.  The  TA  will  require  96  person-months  of  consulting  services  (32  person-months 
international and 64 person-months national) to implement the TA components in the four pilot 
countries. All consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). A consulting firm will be engaged to 
provide the services of a team of international consultants consisting of a team leader and 
systems architecture specialist (5 person-months), systems architecture specialist (8 person-
months), and two remote sensing specialists (total 13 person-months). For the selection of a 
main consulting firm, the quality- and cost-based selection (90:10) method will be used because 
of the highly specialized skill requirements and experience to achieve expected outputs, and the 
firm will be required to submit bio-data technical proposals. In addition, international individual 
consultants  will  be  engaged—a  training  program  specialist  for  4  person-months  and  an 
agricultural statistician for 2 person-months. National remote sensing specialists in the four pilot 
countries will also be engaged for 4 person-months each. Two national consultants assigned in 
ADB headquarters will also be engaged (for 24 person-months each) to assist the ADB project 
team in coordinating the project, organizing the training programs and workshops, and resolving 
and documenting technical issues. The consultants will work under the overall supervision of the 
ADB project team with the technical support of JAXA. The terms of reference for the consultants 
are in Appendix 3. 
 
20.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). Procurement of 
equipment will follow ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). At 
the end of the project, equipment purchased through the shopping method under the TA will be 
assigned to the concerned implementing agencies and TA outputs such as rice area maps, 
software  application,  data,  and  information  will  be  turned  over  to  the  Southeast  Asia 
Department’s GMS Environment Operations Center, the information clearing house for GMS 
working group on environment and related sectors. 
 
IV.  THE RANKING VICE-PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION  
 
21.  The  Ranking  Vice-President,  acting  in  the  absence  of  the  President,  under  the 
provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, recommends that the Board 
approve ADB administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 to 
be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for Innovative Data 
Collection Methods for Agricultural and Rural Statistics.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  International Consultants: Consulting Firm 
1.  A consulting firm will be engaged using the quality- and cost-based selection method 
(90:10) to provide the services of two system architecture specialists and two remote sensing 
specialists. These consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The following are the required 
general qualifications, specific tasks, and expected outputs of the consultants.  
 
  1.  Systems Architecture Specialist and Team Leader (5 person-months)  
2.  The specialist shall have a graduate degree in software program development with 
specialization in remote sensing technology, earth science, or information and communication 
technology,  and  preferably  some  experience  in  agricultural  statistics  remote  sensing 
applications. He or she shall have more than 5 years of experience in earth observation satellite 
(EOS) data analysis in Asia and the Pacific. 
 
3.  The specialist will  
 (i)  review existing agricultural and rural statistics and food security data systems in 
the Lao People's Democratic Republic (Lao PDR), Philippines, Thailand, and Viet 
Nam; 
(ii)  define the system requirements for implementation of the first component of the 
technical  assistance  (TA)  using  remote  sensing,  including  radar  data  of  the 
advanced land observation satellite (ALOS), ALOS-2, and satellite optical data 
that are freely accessible; 
(iii)  design and develop system architectures, including data and work flow based on 
system requirements defined in (ii); 
(iv)  contribute  to  the  development  of  the  implementation  plan  and  evaluate  the 
accomplishment  of  the  TA’s  first  component,  including  conducting  the 
demonstration activity in the Lao PDR, Philippines, Thailand, and Viet Nam;  
(v)  coordinate  the  development,  validation,  and  implementation  of  systems  for 
constructing crop area maps and estimating production; and 
(vi)  submit monthly progress reports to the TA project team leader. 
 
  2.  Systems Architecture Specialist (8 person-months)   
4.  The specialist shall have a graduate degree in software program development with 
specialization in remote sensing technology, earth science, or  information and communication 
technology,  and  preferably  some  experience  in  agricultural  statistics  remote  sensing 
applications. He or she shall have more than 5 years of experience in EOS data analysis in Asia 
and the Pacific. 
 
5.  The specialist will 
(i)  assist the systems architecture specialist (team leader) in defining the system 
requirements  for  implementation  of  the  TA’s  first  component  using  remote 
sensing including radar data of ALOS, ALOS-2, and satellite optical data that are 
freely accessible;

sensing  data  including  radar  data  of  ALOS  and  ALOS-2  to  make  rice  crop 
planted area maps in the four pilot countries; 
(iv)  design and develop systems including software to estimate and validate rice crop 
yield from satellite-based rice crop planted area maps and other data from field 
surveys in the four pilot countries; 
(v)  develop software architecture, program, and test documents and quality control 
documents of the developed system for practitioners in the four countries; 
(vi)  act as resource persons on systems and architecture for the training program in 
the four pilot countries; and 
(vii)  assist the training specialist in developing the online training materials for the use 
of remote sensing data for agricultural and rural statistics. 
 
3.  Remote Sensing Specialists (two specialists, 5 person-months and 8 person-
months, total 13 person-months)  
 
6.  The specialists are expected to have a master’s degree in remote sensing technology, 
earth science, or a comparable discipline and shall have more than 8 years of experience in 
EOS data analysis of ALOS, Moderate-resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS), and 
Global Satellite Mapping of Precipitation (GSMAP), or have conducted research studies on 
remote sensing. 
 
7.  The specialists shall perform the following tasks: 
(i)  develop a methodology for rice crop monitoring using synthetic aperture radar 
(SAR) and space technology with field survey and rice crop growth model in 
Thailand and develop the technical documentation of the methodology; 
(ii)  assist national remote sensing specialists to ensure the quality of outputs; review 
existing  projects  and  programs  for  rice  crop  monitoring  in  the  Lao  PDR, 
Philippines, Thailand, and Viet Nam; reflect the necessary actions to the TA 
outputs;  and  support  the  team  leader  to  prepare  implementation  materials, 
monthly  activity  summaries,  and  reports  (inception,  midterm,  draft  final,  and 
final); and 
(iii)  assist the training program specialist in developing the online training materials 
for the use of remote sensing data for agricultural and rural statistics. 
 
4.   Consulting Firm Outputs 
 
8.  The expected outputs for the consulting firm will be 
(i)  monthly progress reports; 
(ii)  implementation materials (inception report, midterm report, draft final report, and 
final report);  
(iii)  system including software to process and validate remote sensing data including 
radar data of ALOS and ALOS-2 to make rice crop planted area maps in the four 
pilot countries; 
(iv)  system including software to estimate and validate paddy rice crop yield from 
satellite-based rice crop planted area maps and other data from field survey and 
national data in the four countries;

12  Appendix 3 
(v)  technical documents regarding (a) the methodology for rice crop monitoring using 
SAR and space technology with field survey and rice crop growth model; and (b) 
system and software requirement and architecture, program, test documents, 
and quality control documents of the developed system for practitioners in the 
four countries; and 
(vi)  technical report on the existing agricultural and rural statistics and food security 
data systems in the Lao PDR, Philippines, Thailand, and Viet Nam. 
 
B.  International Consultants: Individual  
9.  Individual  international  consultants  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
  1.  Training Program Specialist (4 person-months)  
10.  The specialist is expected to have a doctorate in remote sensing technology, earth 
science,  or  a  comparable  discipline  and  shall  have  more  than  8  years  of  experience  in 
developing  training  materials  for  interactive  internet  access  on  SAR  rice  crop  estimation 
software or agricultural and rural statistics, and preferably on remote sensing data. 
 
11.  The specialist shall perform the following tasks: 
(i)  develop  a  TA  capacity  development  program  with  the  support  of  other 
consultants; 
(ii)  develop a handbook on the use of the remote sensing data for estimating paddy 
rice area and production; 
(iii)  develop  an  online  training  program  on  the  use  of  remote  sensing  data  for 
agricultural and rural statistics based on the methodology developed in the Lao 
PDR,  Philippines,  Thailand,  and  Viet  Nam  and  other  research  results  and 
materials and with the assistance of the remote sensing specialists and systems 
architecture specialists; and 
(iv)  refine the online training program on the basis of users’ comments and other 
feedback. 
 
12.  The expected outputs will be a handbook on the use of the remote sensing data for 
estimating paddy rice area and production, and an online training program on the use of remote 
sensing data for estimating paddy rice area and production that is accessible through the 
internet. 
 
  2.  Agricultural Statistician (2 person-months)  
13.  The specialist is expected to have a graduate degree in statistics and shall have at least 
5  years  of experience  in  compiling  crop  production  statistics,  preferably  using  crop-cutting 
methods. He or she shall have experience in field surveys and in developing survey operations 
manuals. 
 
14.  The agricultural statistician shall assist the project team leader in developing a standard 
procedure across the four pilot countries for validating crop production estimates through crop-
cutting procedures, and participate in training programs as resource person for field surveys for 
validating rice production.

Appendix 3  13 
15.  The expected outputs will be a standard procedure for validating paddy rice production 
estimates through crop cutting that can be implemented across the four pilot countries, and 
training materials for validating crop production estimates through crop-cutting procedures for 
practitioners in the pilot countries. 
 
C.  National Consultants: Individual 
16.  Individual national consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
  1.  National  Remote  Sensing  Specialists  (four specialists for 4 person-months 
each, total 16 person-months)  
17.  The specialists shall have a graduate degree in remote sensing, earth science, or a 
comparable discipline and experience in the field of EOS data analysis, especially for radar 
satellite data including ALOS and ALOS-2. They will also have more than 8 years of experience 
in EOS data analysis of SAR and optical sensor, preferably in ALOS and MODIS or have 
conducted research studies on remote sensing. 
 
18.  One specialist will work with the international remote sensing specialists and counterpart 
staff of the designated implementing agency in each of the four pilot countries to perform the 
following tasks: 
(i)  work  with  the  implementing  agency’s  counterpart  staff  in  processing  and 
validating remote sensing data including radar data of ALOS and ALOS-2 to 
construct rice crop planted area maps; 
(ii)  provide  on-the-job  training  to  counterpart  staff  on  the  use  of  the  software 
applications for estimating rice crop area and production; 
(iii)  estimate and validate rice crop yield from satellite-based rice crop planted area 
maps and other data from field survey in the designated pilot country; 
(iv)  assist the consulting firm in developing the systems by customizing them into 
local language and refining them for use in each country; 
(v)  lead preparation of implementation documentation for the proposed methodology 
including data processing, estimation, calibration, and validation for practitioners 
in the assigned pilot country; and   
 (vi)  assist the training specialist in developing the online training materials for the use 
of remote sensing data for agricultural and rural statistics. 
 
19.  The expected outputs will be monthly progress reports, processed and validated remote 
sensing radar data of ALOS and ALOS-2 for the pilot province, paddy rice maps, paddy rice 
area and production estimates for the pilot province, and implementation documentation for the 
proposed methodology in the pilot province. 
 
  2.  Agricultural Statisticians (two consultants for 24 person-months each, total 48 
person-months)  
20.  The consultants will be assigned to ADB headquarters to work with the project team. 
The specialists shall each have a graduate degree in a field relevant to agricultural and rural 
statistics. They will have experience in managing agricultural research projects in coordination 
with various organizations, data processing and analysis, and disseminating research results.
